_common.name: (V10.0.0.3) Business transaction monitoring
_common.shortDescription: Learn how to monitor business transactions on IBM Integration Bus Version 10.0.0.3
_common._resourceToOpenComment: The ID of the first resource to open when the user imports the tutorial. Resource IDs are defined in the repo_metadata.json Tutorials listing on ot4i.

pageDetails._topicListComment: A short list of product concepts or tasks demonstrated by this tutorial

topicList.title: Configuring monitoring event sources in the message flow editor
Creating a business trasaction definition and monitoring business transactions in the web user interface

pageDetails._outcomesComment: A description of what the user will have learned or accomplished by running this tutorial.

outcomeList.title: Use IBM Integration Bus to monitor business transactions.

summary._overviewComment: A short description of what happens in this tutorial, and an optional short explanation of the IIB concepts used in this tutorial if necessary for context. What background knowledge must the user have for this to make sense?

sections.section: Note: This Business transaction monitoring tutorial requires WebSphere MQ and a database (DB2Â® or Oracle).
A business transaction is a self-contained business function; for example, the booking of an airline ticket.
On IBM Integration Bus, a business transaction may often be implemented using multiple message flows in different applications.
Business transaction monitoring involves tracking the lifecycle of a message across the message flows that make up a business transaction.

helpLinks._helpLinksComment: Helplinks that have a type:web attribute are rendered as web links. Otherwise, links are assumed to be to embedded Help topics in the Knowledge Center.
helpLinks.title: Find out more

overview.name: Create
overview._createComment: A description of what will happen when the user clicks Import.

details.details: Click Import to import the implementation of a retail solution into your workspace. The solution contains the following:

Application BTM_RETAIL_APP is the entry point.
Main_Process_Order_Flow.msgflow routes an incoming message to one of BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP, BTM_RETAIL_PURCHASE_ITEM_APP, BTM_RETAIL_STOCK_CHECK_APP for further processing depending on the type of request.

Application BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP is invoked if the type of request is "orderItem". Order_Item_Request_Flow.msgflow receives the request. Order_Item_Despatch_Flow.msgflow processes the request and Order_Item_Response_Flow.msgflow sends a confirmation.

Application BTM_RETAIL_PURCHASE_ITEM_APP is invoked if the type of request is "purchaseItem". Purchase_Item_Request_Flow.msgflow receives the request. Process_Payment_Flow.msgflow processes the request and Purchase_Item_Response_Flow.msgflow sends a confirmation.

Application BTM_RETAIL_STOCK_CHECK_APP is invoked if the type of request is "stockCheck". Stock_Check_Request_Flow.msgflow receives the request. Check_Stock_Flow.msgflow processes the request and Stock_Check_Response_Flow.msgflow sends a confirmation.
Shared library BTM_RETAIL_SHARED_LIBRARY contains the message model used by the solution.

All message flows have monitoring events configured on a number of their message nodes.
For this tutorial, all monitoring events use $Root/XMLNSC/btm_retail/customerNumber as the global correlator. To see an example, open Main_Process_Order_Flow.msgflow, select "Receive Retail Request" node, click the Monitoring tab in the Properties view.

For simplicity, this tutorial will only monitor the messages processed by BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP. Once you have completed this tutorial, you can explorer further by creating more business transaction definitions using the message flows in the other applications.
Create the default IBM Integration Bus queues
Open the IBM Integration Console.

In the console window, type
server\sample\wmq\iib_createqueues qmgr
where
qmgr is the queue manager name
Create the queues used by the MQ nodes in this tutorial

In the console window, type
runmqsc qmgr
where
qmgr is the queue manager name

Copy and paste the following into the console window to create the queues:
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_FAILUREQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_UNKNOWN_ORDER_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_DESPATCH_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_DESPATCH_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_STOCK_CHECK_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_STOCK_CHECK_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_PROCESS_STOCK_CHECK_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_PROCESS_STOCK_CHECK_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_PURCHASE_ITEM_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_PURCHASE_ITEM_OUTQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_PROCESS_PAYMENT_INQ) replace
define qlocal(BTM_RETAIL_PROCESS_PAYMENT_OUTQ) replace
Associate the default integration node with the queue manager

In the console window, stop the default integration node.
mqsistop -i TESTNODE_userid

Associate the queue manager with the default integration node, TESTNODE_userid
mqsichangebroker TESTNODE_userid -q qmgr
where
qmgr is the queue manager name

Start the default integration node.
mqsistart TESTNODE_userid
Drag and drop BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP and BTM_RETAIL_SHARED_LIBRARY onto an integration server of TESTNODE_userid.
Note: BTM_RETAIL_APP will be deployed in a later step.
Right-click on TESTNODE_userid in the Integration Nodes view and select Start Web User Interface.

Create a business transaction definition
In the web user interface, expand Business -> Business Transactions. Select Create from the menu to create a new business transaction. Enter RetailOrderBTD. Click OK.
Add message flows to the business transaction definition
In the Define tab of RetailOrderBTD, click Add flow to select the message flows that make up this business transaction.
Inside the popup, click Select application, then click the dropdown and select BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP. Click Add to add all the message flows in this application to RetailOrderBTD.

Observe that Order_Item_Request_Flow.msgflow, Order_Item_Despatch_Flow.msgflow, and Order_Item_Response_Flow.msgflow are added to the Business Transaction section.
The warning icon indicates that no start and end events have been defined for this business transaction.
Select the monitoring events that indicate the start, end, and failure of the business transaction definition. In the Business Transaction Event Definitions section,
Expand Order_Item_Request_Flow.msgflow, flag the "Order Item Request Received" event as the Start event.
Expand Order_Item_Despatch_Flow.msgflow, flag the "Item Despatched" event as the Progress event.
Expand Order_Item_Response_Flow.msgflow, flag the "Confirm Item Ordered" event as the End event.
Save RetailOrderBTD.

overview.name: Prepare
overview._prepareComment: A description of what just happened when the user clicked Import, and what will happen when the user clicks Deploy.

details.details:
Run this script to create the database MBRECORD and monitoring events tables:
IIBInstallDir/server/ddl/db/DataCaptureSchema.sql
where
IIBInstallDir is the installed location of IBM Integration Bus Version 10.0.0.3, and
db is either db2 or oracle.
Note:To customize the database or schema name used by business transaction monitoring, edit DataCaptureSchema.sql before running it.

Run this script to create the tables for recording and storing business transaction data:
IIBInstallDir/server/ddl/db/BusinessCaptureSchema.sql
Note: If you modified the name of the database in the previous step, you'll need to update the database name in BusinessCaptureSchema.sql before running it.

Define a ODBC data source name (DSN), MBRECORD, for the database MBRECORD.
Follow the link Enabling ODBC connections to the databases in the Find out more section below for instructions on configuring an ODBC data source for your operating system.
Note: If you modified the name of the database in the previous steps, use the same name for your DSN name in this step.
Set a user id and password for the integration node to use when connecting to the database.
Open the IBM Integration Console.

In the console window, type
mqsisetdbparms TESTNODE_userid -n DSN -u id -p password
where
TESTNODE_userid is the default integration node
DSN is the data source name created in the previous step
id and password are the user id and password used to connect to the database MBRECORD

Optional: Verify the user id and password for the database is set correctly by typing
mqsireportdbdbparms TESTNODE_userid -n DSN -u id -p password

Restart the integration node.
In the console window, type
mqsistop -i TESTNODE_userid
After the default integration node is stopped, type
mqsistart TESTNODE_userid

Optional: Test the connection to the database MBRECORD.
In the console window, type
mqsicvp TESTNODE_userid -n DSN

sections.section: Configure the database to be used for the business transaction definition

details.details: Open the Web User Interface.
Expand Business -> Business Transactions. Select RetailOrderBTD.
Select the Configure tab. Note that RetailOrderBTD is not yet configured with a data source.
Click Click here to specify a data source name. Select the data source name MBRECORD from the dropdown.

Click Save to save the datasource name. Then click Resume editing of business transaction RetailOrderBTD to return to the Configure tab.
Note: MBRecord will be used to record all the business transactions for this integration node.

In the web user interface, expand Servers -> server -> Applications -> BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP
where
server is the integration server where BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP is deployed.
Select Start flow monitoring from the menu of BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP.

overview.name: Run
overview._runComment: The full steps for the user to run through the tutorial. Use 'sections' to render paragraphs, 'steps' with a type of 'ordered' or 'unordered' to render HTML lists, and 'substeps' to render nested lists.

details.details: Open Main_Process_Order_Flow. Click the Flow Exerciser icon to start recording the message path through the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow. Choose Cookie Monster's Order. Note the "requestType" is "orderItem" and "customerNumber" is "5555". Click Send.
After the response message is received, the message path is highlighted on the message flow. You may click on any connection to see the message that passed through that connection.
Click the Send Message icon again. Choose Panda Po's Order. Note the "requestType" is "orderItem" and "customerNumber" is "5670". Click Send.
Click the Send Message icon again. Choose Winnie the Pooh's Order. Note the "requestType" is "orderItem" and "customerNumber" is "4785". Click Send.

sections.section: All 3 transactions were processed by the message flows in BTM_RETAIL_ORDER_ITEM_APP and captured by RetailOrderBTD. You will now be able to view the results in the Web User Interface.

details.details: Open the Web User Interface.
Expand Business -> Business Transactions. Select RetailOrderBTD. Select the View tab.
Click Refresh in the All instsances of RetailOrderBTD section. 3 instances, identified by the global transaction ID "customerNumber", will be shown. All instances have the status of "Ended".
Click on an instance. The 3 associated events, "Order Item Request Received", "Item Despatched", "Confirm Item Ordered", and their corresponding details will be shown in the Events section.

Optionally, to show only the instances with a specified global transaction ID, or those that have a particular status, click Filter in the All instsances of RetailOrderBTD section to specify the filtering criteria.
